Posts.Content: Jude58 I am 59 and had breast cancer with 3 lots of surgery, one of them being a mastectomy, radiotherapy and chemotherapy. I was a full time secretary prior to this. I have struggled so much being back at work. The fatigue is so debilitating. I would love to give up work but at the moment waiting till I'm 60 next March. I can get my pension then which is not enough to survive on. I could work part time 3 days a week to supplement it. What I wanted to ask does anyone know if in those circumstances and if my doctor would do a note saying I'm not fit enough to be able to work could I claim benefits? I feel guilty thinking this but at the moment I'm barely coping and just existing.
Posts.Title: Giving up work

Posts.Content: Thank you all for your support, I have checked with McMillan ..... And think I may need an employment lawyer, I've had security with my job and now I feel it's been taken away
Posts.Title: Worried sick

Posts.Content: I've been off work for 8 nearly 9 months to go through treatment, chemo , operation, and 30 rads , chemo strong as 3 tumours and tnbc, work agreed to pay me during this time, I'm still recovering, suffered on chemo and radiotherapy and have developed a cough which I've had since end of feb, now work have said they are stopping paying me so I've been put on ssp, contractually I believe they can, my last pay was not full pay, as they have previously done , but as commissioned based hey Ho, I was asked to meet for a coffee and chat, prior to knowing any of this, and was not given any notice...... and told it only may happen if I didnt submit a phased plan to return and it was down to me, but this had already been dealt with prior to coffee and chat !I believe it was formal meeting as another manager present and was told unless plan to return to work was put in, my md would make that decision but the decision was already made ...... I've put phased plan in which they should have received at latest by Tuesday and confirmed it was sent, but nothing back ....... I've worked for this company for almost 19 years ...... I'm stressed and upset beyond belief .......
Posts.Title: Worried sick

Posts.Content: Hi, I managed to stay clear of infection whilst having chemo, after finishing radiotherapy, developed a cough, unrelated to RT, but lasted three months, after tests seems asthma has returned. Back at work for one week,  managed to get a cold and cough. This is 6 months post chemo, I guess we have to be patient, we need time to recover xx
Posts.Title: Antibodies

Posts.Content: Hi York A, I was diagnosed at the end of July, two lumps and grade 3, I made the decision to have chemo first FEC-T and my operation was on the 21st of December, results yesterday said clear margins and no cancer in the lymph nodes. I am TN so will have radiotherapy. Keeping positive and trying to keep as normal as possible has got me through, I did not succumb to google searching just followed this group which has been a massive support even though they haven't known it, but this is where you will get your answers.  On my down times, not many of them, my sons and close friends would remind me that the side affects I have faced are only temporary and that in itself is a positive thought. Try and occupy your mind as much as possible believe me it does help with the positive attitude. Your body will amaze you of what it is capable of dealing with. So go fight this critter and you can beat it ...... After all the first three letters of the word say you can.  I have had marvellous support from my oncologist and surgeon so put your trust in them too.  Soups xx
Posts.Title: reigning in the fear

Posts.Content: Keep going .....we are all here to help xx
Posts.Title: reigning in the fear

Posts.Content: Hi Tilly, Stick with all the chemo if you can, I've just had my 3rd cycle of FEC t but mine is the other way round to yours, I've not been or felt sick, just tired and remember that can include the emotional journey too. My tumours have really shrunk and I'm chuffed. The first 3 have gone really quickly as will the next three, I cross them off and know that the next one I will be two thirds done.  Speak to your oncologist but stick with it if you can, give yourself the best chance of beating it's ass Lol.   nicky

Posts.Title: Help ......

Posts.Content: I was diagnosed with grade 3 invasive TNC at the end of July 2015, I have had 6 cycles of FEC-T and suffered with the T ..... Lumpectomy on 21st Dec and started rads yesterday, not pleasant as I'm doing the deep inhalation and can't stand anything in my mouth. I asked my breast care nurse for a letter for work, my oncologist has booked an appointment to see me 6 weeks after rads finish to assess me, so the letter says I should be fit 3 weeks after rads finish. I haven't come to terms with the emotional side at all and work will now expect me to return then.... I'm told I'm being moved to an area 40 miles from home but can start back phased to do this ...... I'm in shock, I'm not ready, I'm tired and still need to get my head round it all ..... Any advice please
Posts.Title: Help ......

Posts.Content: Take care and with courage and believe in that " the hearts we leave behind us is not to die" it's a hard road but I lost my dad and brother to bowel cancer and my mum to Alzheimer's........ I look at butterfly's and believe it's my mum fluttering around me and my dad loved kestrels so I always feel safe when I see one..... Take your time as we all have to xx
Posts.Title: Falling apart now it's over

Posts.Content: Totally normal, I'm pretty crap at replying and commentating on this site, I've had lots of melt downs and I think it's how we define ourselves now after being on that roller coaster ..... I haven't found a support group that has been through all our experiences, I have managed to get some counselling and my counsellor knows of specific groups such as young persons being diagnosed and secondary breast cancer...... I want to start a group for us .... The ones that feel lonely after treatment  Believe me it's normal x
